terms.definition: A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and track modifications.
A single, organized storage location where all documents are kept and can be accessed by authorized users from one platform.
The process of monitoring and ensuring that documentation and processes meet regulatory requirements and industry standards.
A chronological record of document changes, user actions, and system events that provides transparency and accountability.
The ability to make and view changes to documents instantly as they occur, allowing multiple users to collaborate simultaneously.
The process of sharing information, skills, and expertise from one person or team to another within an organization.
Detailed written materials that explain how systems work, including specifications, procedures, and operational guidelines.
Software or services that are hosted on remote servers and accessed via the internet rather than installed locally.
The ability to revert a document or system to a previous version or state when errors or issues occur.
Working together across different departments, teams, or areas of expertise to achieve common goals.
Research and Development - the process of investigating and creating new products, technologies, or improvements to existing systems.
Software as a Service - a software delivery model where applications are hosted in the cloud and accessed via subscription.
Internet of Things - a network of connected devices that can collect and exchange data over the internet.
Artificial Intelligence - computer systems that can perform tasks typically requiring human intelligence, such as analysis and decision-making.
An international standard that specifies requirements for environmental management systems to help organizations improve their environmental performance.
